key_points: Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube removed a video of President Donald Trump addressing his supporters during the Capitol riot.
In the video, Trump sympathized with the rioters and repeated false claims about the election being stolen.
Facebook and Twitter locked President Trump's accounts, citing policy violations.
Facebook's ban on Trump's account is extended indefinitely, at least through the end of his term, according to CEO Mark Zuckerberg.
Twitter suspended Trump's account for 12 hours and warned of permanent suspension for further rules violation.
Trump's video urged protesters to go home while continuing to make unfounded claims about the election.
Facebook initially imposed a 24-hour restriction before extending the ban, aiming for a peaceful transition of power.
Facebook and Twitter took emergency actions due to the ongoing violence and violation of civic integrity policies.
YouTube removed the Trump video for violating policies against fraud claims but allows reuploads with sufficient context.
The video remains available on the Trump campaign's Parler page, gaining 1.3 million views.
spokespersons: Guy Rosen (Oversees work on safety and integrity, Facebook)
